testimony: Can we proceed with the next applicant?
The next applicant Chairperson is Marius Etienne Visser.  His application appears on page 84 of the bundle which is placed before you.
Do you have any objection to taking the Oath Mr Visser?
Do you confirm that the evidence which you will deliver will be the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth?

Thank you Chairperson, may I proceed?  Very well, Mr Visser you along with the other applicants in this matter were arrested and prosecuted in the Supreme Court of the Witwatersrand on charges of murder and various other charges of which you were found guilty.  Is that correct.
And in the Supreme Court you were given the death penalty initially?
And is it correct that at a later stage your case was referred back to the courts by the Appeal Court where you were given a prison sentence?

You are applying for amnesty for the charges of murder and other charges of which you were found guilty as set out in the judgment of Justice Marais who found you guilty and sentenced you.  Is that correct?
You have studied your application which appears on page 84 and goes on until page 100 and appears in the record.  Do you confirm that?

Just another aspect Honourable Chairperson, that's on page 87 of the application, question 10.a should be amended to refer to:  See Annexure A, not B.  That would be on page 87.  I beg your pardon Chairperson I think I'm actually making an error.  Mr Visser in the family in which you grew up, was it conservative or liberal?
It was of a conservative nature.
And which party did you support since 1990?
The Volksfront as well as all the right wing organisations such as the AWB and the SACP.
Did you receive any military training?
And at that stage, the ANC and SACP and other parties had already been unbanned?
Before the unbanning of these parties in 1990 or the talk thereof, what were your sentiments and the sentiments of your family?

In the climate of the circumstances we could surmise that things were becoming tense regarding the situation with the ANC and SACP members.  One could see that they were going to come into power and we regarded this as a very tense climate.
For which reason did you join the AWB?
I believed in the ideology of the AWB and the objectives for which they stood, that would be for God the Volk and the Fatherland for an own language and a culture.

As time went by you've already testified that after the unbanning of the ANC a possibility existed that they would rule the country.  What was the sentiment and the viewpoint of the AWB with regard to that.
Their opinion was that they would never allow the ANC, SACP alliance and that class of organisation to simply take over the country.
At any stage during that period of time did you attend any meetings of the AWB?
And those meetings which you attended, who were the chief speakers in leadership function?
Eugene Terreblanche as well as Constand Viljoen attended some of the meetings.
And during those meetings, did you experience any influence over you?
That is correct.  The meetings went hand in hand with sweeping up against the ANC and the SACP.
Did you receive the impression that the leadership of the AWB would allow the ANC and SACP to take over the government and the country?
Was there any talk of war within that climate?
Were any arrangements made for any violence which would be committed and that people should prepare themselves for this?
That's correct.  People had to arm themselves as said by the leader of the AWB, Mr Eugene Terreblanche.
In which area did you reside in 1993?
And who was the commanding general of that area?
The other applicants over here - Commandant Kloppers, who has testified shortly before you, did he occupy any position of authority in your area?
He was the Chief Commandant of Area 9.
He was the Commandant of Area 9.
Did you fall under his command?
And what rank did you occupy within the AWB at that stage in 1993?
At that stage I was an assistant Commandant.
Did you therefore fall within the command of Mr Martin and then others below you?
The other co-applicants, apart from those which I have mentioned, did they fall within your command or were they of equal rank, what were there positions?
Mr Van der Schyff occupied the same rank as I did and if I remember correctly, the other applicants occupied lower ranks that I did.
On the 12th of December 1993 you were called to a Roadhouse in the Randfontein area?
Mr Badenhorst, one of the applicants, came to fetch me at my girlfriend's house and told me that Commandant Martins' wife had issued an order that we meet at the Roadhouse.
Did you go there in uniform?
From there we went to Mr Badenhorst's house.  My uniform was at his house.
I had no arm, I didn't possess any arm.
So you went to the Roadhouse unarmed?
And at the Roadhouse, it has been testified that a meeting took place.  Were you addressed by Mr Kloppers at this Roadhouse?
Chief Commandant Kloppers arrived last of all.
Were any weapons handed out to anybody at the Roadhouse?
Some of us didn't have weapons.  Myself, Gert Diedericks and Mr Van der Schyff didn't have weapons and upon that Mr Kloppers produced two pipe shotguns from his vehicle.
And who did he gives these to?
The pipe shotguns were given to myself and Mr Diedericks.
Did Mr Diedericks and yourself keep the pipe shotguns?
No, it was taken from Mr Diedericks.
It wouldn't have come out but Mr Van der Schyff said that he would show Mr Diedericks how to shoot a kaffir.
Were any orders issued to you from anybody there at the Roadhouse?
All of us were brought to attention when Mr Kloppers arrived and Commandant Martin saluted Chief Commandant Kloppers.

Chief Commandant Kloppers told us that he had just come from an order group meeting and that he had received orders there that we were going to execute the hard option that night and that they wanted to see corpses.
Was anything else said which you can recall?
Yes, that this would be the real McCoy.
Not as far as I can recall.
And what did you understand by executing the hard option and that this was the real McCoy and that there had to be corpses?
As I understood it hard options would mean that people would be killed or injured.  That's what I understood under the concept of hard option.
And what did you understand when a homemade pipe shotgun was given to you?

When I received the pipe shotgun I knew that people would be killed because two weeks before the time we were placed on assistance because of the revolution which was supposed to begin.  It was said to us that the revolution was about to begin.
When was it said to you that the revolution was about to begin?
The night of the 12th of December, at the roadside, it was said to us that the revolution was at hand.
Mr Kloppers said this to us.
After you had completed the parade, received the gun and received your orders did you go anywhere from there?
If I remember correctly we arrived in four or five vehicles at the Roadhouse and after that we went to Mr Badenhorst's house because his parents were away on vacation.
And what happened at Mr Badenhorst's house?
There Chief Commandant Kloppers decided that only two vehicles would be used for the operation.
And whose vehicles would it be?
The Mercedes of Commandant Martins and the Sentra of Mr Visser.
Were any changes brought to the vehicles?
That's correct.  The number plates were closed up with masking tape.
Did that happen with both vehicles?
Mr Visser's vehicle as well as Mr Martin's vehicle?
And at Mr Badenhorst's house, did anyone consume any alcohol?
And from Mr Badenhorst's house, where did you go then?
We then went to Andre Visser's apartment.
He's also one of the applicants?
Was any alcohol consumed at Mr Visser's home?
Mr Visser produced a bottle of whisky and each one of us took a sip of the whisky.
How full was the bottle of whisky?
I would say it was about three quarters of the way full.
And did Mr Diedericks use any alcohol?
And after the alcohol had been consumed, where did you go then, from Mr Visser's house?
From there we moved in the vehicles to Commandant Martin's small holding.
It was said to us that we would establish a roadblock and reflectors and a blue light were produced.
And after they were brought out, or let me put it this way, was any alcohol consumed at Mr Martin's house that you knew or saw of?
As far as I recall I think there was brandy.
And from Mr Martin's small holding, where did you go then?

Mr Martin, Chief Commandant Kloppers, Gert Diedericks and I travelled in the Mercedes and the others travelled in the Sentra and so we drove among the small holdings because we didn't know where to establish the roadblock.
Did anything happen while you were traveling which you saw yourself, not what you heard about?
That's correct.  Two Black men were moving along the side of the road, the Sentra stopped and the occupants climbed out and assaulted those two Black men.
Did the other vehicle join up with you again?
And where did you go then?
From there we went to the Ridora Crossing.
And when you say Ridora Crossing, in which area would that be?
That would be on the Ventersdorp, Krugersdorp road.
And what happened there.  Did you stop, what happened?
With our arrival there Mr Kallie Meiring was instructed to point out our positions to us, who had to stand where, who had to do what, who had to position the blue light and so forth.
Mr Meiring is also an applicant in this case?
Is that with regard to the establishment of a road block?
Kallie Meiring was instructed because he had previous knowledge of roadblocks.
And which function would you perform at this roadblock?
Me and Mr Badenhorst would stand behind the chevron board for observation.
While you took up your positions and the roadblock was set up, did any vehicles approach?

Chief Commandant Kloppers and Commandant Deon Martins told us what the routine would be, that they would drive along, that they would seek out a target, that they would turn around and drive back and flash their headlights at us, that we had to drive along then and pull the vehicle off the road.
Was any use made of the blue light or any light whatsoever?
That's correct, the blue light was mounted on the Sentra.
Do you know who manned it?
Were any vehicles pulled off the road?
And regarding those vehicles that were pulled off the road, was anything done to them?
The vehicles were searched and questions were put and I assume that the occupants were asked to which political parties they belonged, where they were going, what they were doing and so forth.
Did you participate in the inspection or the searching of the vehicles?
As I've mentioned, I stood behind the chevron board looking out for police or military vehicles which might be approaching.
Did you perform any other function there?
... (indistinct) according to the evidence a Honda Ballade and a Toyota vehicle were pulled off the road.  Is that correct?
It was a Toyota Cressida and a Honda Ballade.

Chief Commandant Kloppers and Commandant Martins drove along, identified a target, flashed their headlights and gave us the signal to pull the vehicles off the road.  At that stage we didn't know that it was a Honda and a Cressida.  At approximately 250 metres before the roadblock the vehicles stopped.

Chief Commandant Kloppers warned us to be careful because people could climb out the vehicles or remove things.  And the vehicle moved closer to us and the men who was the traffic cops when the vehicles were completely off the road told them to get out of the vehicles.
Is this now the Cressida and the Honda Ballade?
Can you remember which vehicle was in front and which vehicle was at the back?
Afterwards the people were told to sit on a hill next to the road and the people who acted as the traffic cops went ahead, it was Matthews, Van der Schyff and I think Mr Diedericks.
And at that stage you were still behind the chevron board?
And after the search was complete, what happened then?
The people who sat on the embankment were approached by Commandant Kloppers and Martins.
Do you know what the interrogation was about?
I knew yes.  Questions were put to them for example where they come from, where they're going, what political party they belong to etc.
And do you know what the answers were to those questions?  In general.
I assumed they were ANC members.
Because the question was put to them, what political party they belonged to.
Chief Commandant Kloppers moved behind the people and those who did not answer he just tapped them on the head and Mr Martin moved in front of the people.

Afterwards Commandant Martin called us from behind the chevron board.  I do not know who was in the group, but that's where the group was formed and it was said to us then that this is the target, SACP and ANC people and this is the target that we must shoot at and that we must shoot on the first shot of Commandant Martins.
What did you do, did you form a line?

After we received the instruction from Chief Commandant Kloppers I walked and found Mr Van der Schyff at one of the vehicle's boots where I said to him that he must get his gun ready, we're going to shoot these people.
I'm referring to the pipe shotgun.
We moved in front of the first vehicle and the first shot was fired and everybody started shooting.
If you say we, does this include Mr Van der Schyff?
Who formed this line and fired?
I assume it was everybody who was there.
Were shots fired towards these people?
How many shots did you fire?
Did you shoot in the direction of the people?
Did you realise at that stage that if you shoot at those people that you could kill them.
And after the shooting stopped, what happened then?
After the shooting stopped people jumped into the Sentra and drove away.
Are you now talking about the group of you?
And the car hadn't even reached full sped then Commandant Kloppers said we will meet them at the Town Hall.
It was me, Kloppers, Martins and Gert Diedericks.
You've already given evidence that Mr Diedericks didn't have a weapon?
What happened then when you stayed behind?
At the scene I picked up some of the shells and Mr Martin and Chief Commandant Kloppers were busy with the people who were lying on the ground.
Do you know something about an ear?
I heard in the vehicle that they cut the ear off.
So you did not see it?

Did you then go with Martins, Kloppers and
Diedericks to the Town Hall.
Yes, we got into the vehicle and from there we went back to Mr Martin's small holding.
Originally did you go directly to the small holding or did you drive somewhere else?
No we went directly to the small holding in order to drop Mr Diedericks off.
We had a drink at his house and from there we went to the Town Hall.
And when you got to the Town Hall, what was the purpose of the Town Hall meeting?
That was the point where we all had to come together.
Mr Chairperson when we got to the Town Hall there was no one there and from the Town Hall we went to Mr Badenhorst's house.
Did you find the other people at Mr Badenhorst's house?

There it was put to us how many shots each
person fired and there everybody admitted that everyone fired a shot.  I don't know if the people were scared when they said that they fired ... (inaudible - end of tape)
Mr Visser did you take part in this action on your own or on behalf of someone?
I did it on behalf of the AWB.
Did you receive any remuneration for this?
Did you shoot at these people because of malice?  On the 16th of December of that same year, did you attend the "Verlofdedag" Festivities?
It was the 16th of December, Covenant Day, we were asked by Commandant Kloppers to attend.
And what happened at the festivities?
We were asked by General Oelofse to form a guard of honour for Mr Terreblanche.
And after you formed this guard of honour did you leave?
Were you arrested by the South African Police?
And then were you detained according to Section 29 of Internal Affairs.  Is that correct?
And did you make a statement to the police officer?
And did you do it of your own free will or what happened?
I would not say of free will Mr Chairperson because it was put to us and our co-accused what would happen to us if we didn't make a statement.
Was there something showed to you, what was showed to you?
Mr Kloppers was shown to me when he was tortured.  I could see it because he did not look normal.  His face was swollen.

And afterwards you appeared in court, pleaded
not guilty.  Is that correct?
Did you given evidence in court?
Did you tell the truth in court?
No, some of the things were not the truth.
To protect myself and higher ranks.
Apart from murder you were also found guilty of the possession of illegal weapons.

Thank you Mr Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR PRINSLOO

Mr Visser I see that in your amnesty application in Annexure A, page 91, that you mention that:  We fulfilled a protection service at some of the meetings where Eugene Terreblanche, Constand Viljoen and Ferdie Hartzenberg were present?  (Transcriber's translation)
Why do you call it a secret meeting?
We were told by Chief Commandant Kloppers that it was a secret meeting.  (Transcriber's translation)
Were you only involved with the security aspect or did you also attend the meetings.
We didn't attend the meetings, we only transported the General and some of the other members to the meetings and ensured their safety.  (Transcriber's translation).

I note also that you make mention that: General Oelofse informed us that the General Staff were invited by the South African Defence Force to view their weaponry.  Was that told to you?  (Transcriber's translation).
It was just told to us Chairperson.

You mention on page 95 that during the roadblock - that is paragraph 12 - the AWB members were dressed in camouflage and you were easily identified as AWB members.  Is that correct?  (Transcriber's translation)
You mention that Phil Kloppers was aggressive.  Can you explain to the Honourable Committee what happened there?

I think it was the person from the Honda, if I remember correctly, he didn't want to co-operate during the searching of his vehicle or he didn't want to climb out of his vehicle and Mr Phil Kloppers smashed the wind bubble with a (indistinct).  (Transcriber's translation).

No further questions, thank you sir.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS VAN DER WALT
